¥hat exa-etly is meant by the term "formalism" as used
by the Sjviet authorities1?
I: ‘'Formalism is usually considered to denote a lack of
ideas, a lack of content, a complete concentration on
fora with no reference to reality.
■When this happens, it may be due not only to laziness,
but to a lack of boldness and courage. Hence the tendency
to imitate Western Bourgeois art and contemporary
modernism. In such cases the composer has not the
strength to look our great future straight in the face*
The composer must struggle against this tendency to
distort, against this laziness, this lack of courage;
and in this struggle he should be greatly helped by
the stern, but friendly care shown him by the Party.'*
From this it would seem that '*formalism1* is about
everything the Soviet leaders don’t happen to like in
music. This definition is reflected in the Central
Committee* s Resolution of 194^ on music. The
Resolution begins with an attack on Muradeli’s opera.
II: "This opera is chaotic and inharmonious, full of
continuous discords which hurt one’s ears. Some
allegedly melodious passages are suddenly broken off
by noises unsuitable to normal human hearing.
“The Central Committee considers that the failure of
Muradeli’s opera is the result of his having followed
the formalist road—a road that has been so pernicious
to the works of Soviet composers....
